description:
To date, when one tries to deposit a spectral line whose line width is below the spectral bin width, `AbsorptionSpectrum` skips that particular line and makes a note to the user to decrease the spectral bin width in order to better resolve all of the lines.  In reality, however, spectrographs look at unresolved lines all the time.  They do this by depositing the light (or optical depth=tau in the case of absorption line spectra) into a much wider bin, yielding a smeared out effect.  This PR recreates this effect.

By creating a virtual array of spectral bins where the line *is* resolved, we deposit the voigt profile, then numerically integrate all of these virtual bins and convert it to an equivalent amount of optical depth on the original spectral bin array: an "equivalent width".  

Furthermore, up until now we have relied on the fact that the spectral array is high enough resolution that it didn't matter if we were treating array elements as discrete locations where the voigt function was sampled, or if the array elements were representing bins.  This PR now firmly defines each array element as a bin *center*.

I have tested this PR, and it yields appropriate answers.  My test found [here](http://paste.yt-project.org/show/6053/) generates AbsorptionSpectrum objects at progressively coarser bin sizes.  It outputs the integrated optical depth across the window for all cases and shows that the total integrated optical depth is conserved with this PR.  It also generates images showing the spectra as the resolution decreases.

As promised, this PR includes tests.

UPDATE1: I added the conservation of optical depth equivalent width to the absorptionspectrum unit tests, as well as a non-cosmological dataset to the unit tests.  I tried to add an answer test, but I cannot figure out how to do this.  It's relatively simple: all i want to do is take one of the `AbsorptionSpectrum` unit tests and save one of the output hdf5 spectra files as an "answer", but this appears to be non-trivial.  Any help on this front is welcome.

UPDATE2: I added an answer test to generate an HI spectra for the enzo_cosmology_plus dataset and compare with an existing standard file.  I will upload that file once all of the changes to `LightRay` and `AbsorptionSpectrum` settle down and are merged (e.g. PR #1856).

UPDATE3: I addressed PR comments, and I added another "answer" test for an HI spectrum generated by a cosmological light ray spanning multiple datasets.  Again, this won't be triggered until after I've uploaded the files to the yt-data site.  I want to get this PR merged, so I will include docs in a future PR.

BEFORE this PR are images going from coarser spectral bin resolutions:

![before_0.001.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/MrnBzM/images/2384584887-before_0.001.png)
![before_0.01.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/MrnBzM/images/3338449231-before_0.01.png)
![before_0.1.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/MrnBzM/images/919908469-before_0.1.png)
![before_1.0.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/MrnBzM/images/4105436197-before_1.0.png)
![before_10.0.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/MrnBzM/images/281380070-before_10.0.png)

AFTER this PR are images going from coarser spectral bin resolutions:
![after_0.001.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/MrnBzM/images/1995555006-after_0.001.png)
![after_0.01.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/MrnBzM/images/4022114285-after_0.01.png)
![after_0.1.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BXbAb/images/1108866932-after_0.1.png)
![after_1.0.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BXbAb/images/499849568-after_1.0.png)
![after_10.0.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BXbAb/images/853870945-after_10.0.png)
title: Enabling AbsorptionSpectrum to deposit unresolved spectral lines

pullrequest.title: Enabling AbsorptionSpectrum to deposit unresolved spectral lines

content.raw:
This looks pretty good to me and seems like a necessary functionality for producing reliable spectra.  Would it be worth include some sort of print statement that let's the user know their spectrum contains poorly resolved lines?  Or should we just trust that they are setting the spectral resolution that they desire and wouldn't care about better resolving lines?

Nice work @chummels!
content.html:
This looks pretty good to me and seems like a necessary functionality for producing reliable spectra. Would it be worth include some sort of print statement that let's the user know their spectrum contains poorly resolved lines? Or should we just trust that they are setting the spectral resolution that they desire and wouldn't care about better resolving lines?

Nice work Cameron Hummels!

pullrequest.title: Enabling AbsorptionSpectrum to deposit unresolved spectral lines

content.raw: @devinsilvia I left in part of the "unresolved" message from before.  When you have unresolved lines, it tells you there are some unresolved lines, but it doesn't tell you to increase resolution as it did before.
content.html: Devin Silvia I left in part of the "unresolved" message from before. When you have unresolved lines, it tells you there are some unresolved lines, but it doesn't tell you to increase resolution as it did before.

content.html: Ah. Ok. I should have looked a bit more closely. I suppose my only question at this point would be if the user will wonder what this means about their resulting spectra. Is this something that would be addressed in the documentation?

pullrequest.title: Enabling AbsorptionSpectrum to deposit unresolved spectral lines

content.raw: The whole `HI_SPECTRUM` vs `HI_SPECTRUM_FILE` thing is a kludge that I put in there to get past some weirdness in the testing infrastructure.  The `@requires_file()` automatically prepends the testing directory to the file provided, which is fine if you're loading a yt dataset.  However, it doesn't seem to work with files just loaded by hdf5 (ie h5py cannot fine the file if I pass `HI_SPECTRUM` to it.  So I had to make the HI_SPECTRUM and HI_SPECTRUM_FILE to give to `@requires_file()` and `h5py.File()` respectively.  It works, but it's a little ugly.
content.html: The whole HI_SPECTRUM vs HI_SPECTRUM_FILE thing is a kludge that I put in there to get past some weirdness in the testing infrastructure. The @requires_file() automatically prepends the testing directory to the file provided, which is fine if you're loading a yt dataset. However, it doesn't seem to work with files just loaded by hdf5 (ie h5py cannot fine the file if I pass HI_SPECTRUM to it. So I had to make the HI_SPECTRUM and HI_SPECTRUM_FILE to give to @requires_file() and h5py.File() respectively. It works, but it's a little ugly.
